course.subject: ENGG
course.name: Robotics Special Project: ABU Robocon 2020
course.description: The Asia-Pacific Robot Contest (ABU Robocon) is an Asian Oceanian College robot competition for young engineers. Student teams will design and manufacture the robots for tackling different missions and challenges which are provided by the organizer. Normally, a project report is required. Enrollment in the project course may require instructor's approval. May be graded PP.

reviews.author: TrebledJ
reviews.title: Action-packed, tense, and challenging on many different levels
reviews.comment_content:
Not a regular course. No exams. (Yay!)

Robocon is an annual competition. You can read about it online.

We recruit new members in the Fall term (be sure to check your email, or visit our webpage). The selection process begins with a workshop, followed by tutorials which are split into mechanical/hardware/software divisions. There would then be a small-scale competition between groups.

In Spring, focus is shifted towards building robots, routing, and coding the robot. Junior members have the opportunity to become game-field members and experience all the action-packed fun and joy of endless practice.

If you're a recluse like me, team-based work may seem intimidating. It's important to keep in mind that being part of the Robotics Team entails regular team communication, meetings, and the whole baggage. By joining the team, you'll get many opportunities to practice soft skills, ask questions, and learn new things. You'll also get to make new friends, meet people from other countries, understand society better, and make the world a better place.

Taking part in robotics also allows you to apply skills you've learned before, ranging from a variety of math problems (trig, differential eqs, multivariable calc), physics (circular motion, torque), 3D-printing skills, debugging skills, and more.
reviews.comment_teaching:
In the Fall semester, senior members will guide and provide tutorials to bring you up to speed. The tutorials tend to have a steep learning curve, but the seniors do their best to answer any questions and provide advice.

For the software division, the tutorials would teach the C language, the primary language we use to programming robots. However, in Robocon, we also use C++ and Python for other tasks.

Although tedious early on, it eases as we enter the Spring semester, where focus is put on the competition. In this period, further self-study, inquiring, and research is needed to understand the topics at hand, may it be robot construction, electronic circuits, or algorithms. It's nice in the sense that it's self-paced.
reviews.comment_grading:
This course is graded from A-F. Generally, the extent of contribution, effort, and time spent correlates with good grades. There will be three peer reviews and one final report. However, the time spent working with the robots far outweighs the time spent writing the reviews and report.

Regular attendance and contribution almost always guarantees A-range.
reviews.comment_workload:
You can expect 3-15 hours per week on a regular school week. Exceptions are usually made for exams. In the summer (after finals and before the competition), expect to be in the lab for 9-12 hours per day. Expect to demo (present) ideas, constructions, robot motion, game flow, etc, depending on your exact role and tasks.

Nobody will put a gun to your head and force you to come everyday and work; but once you get into the team, it becomes a responsibility.

Pretty tough workload, I must say. But it builds character.™️

On the flip side, you get to meat some rice lunchmates and people to hang out with (if you're into hanging out). Moreover, you get to keep funny/sweet/cute moments with the team. So the experience is quite worth it.

reviews.author: Yoyo Lam
reviews.comment_content:
You can learn a lot about robotics and have a hands-on experience through joining the ABU Robocon competition, which is really rewarding, everyone has interests in robotics or enjoy joining competition should have a try.

Design your won robot and build it out and tune it, think of the strategy to beat the other team, which is really fun.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Most of the time, you need self-learning, through youtube or google.

Here are lots of seniors and extraordinary people in any area which you can gain a lot from them. You can ask the superior senior for opinion, they are helpful and willing to teach you a lot. It is a good chance for you to gain a lot of experience and knowledge as well as get a group of good friends.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading is very good, most people got A range. If you are enthusiastic about robotics and the competition, you have a high chance of getting A+ but of course, you have to give sufficient time in the lab and prepare the competition.

I do spend quite a lot of time and be responsible here and at last, the grading is not disappointing, give me an A+.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is actually a lot since it is a huge robotics competition. You need to give your whole spring and summer semester here preparing the competition. However, if you are enthusiastic about robotics and enjoy the teamwork here, you won't really think the teamwork is too much. But of course, you have to be willing to give a lot of time to be here. But you would definitely gain a lot here if you are willing to spend time here.
